title: Typography and Vision Problems
content:
Does anyone have any good sources for Typography and Vision related problems? My THESIS is creating "a designers guide" to vision related problems. Specifically, Central/Peripheral blurriness. In the end I am creating a typeface for this. I am familiar with the AIGA article but I could use more help.

Thankyou,  
Prakash Nair
author: Prakash Nair

There is mention of vision problems and package design in _Can packaging be honest?_ by Frank Philippin (with Indroductory text by Jeremy Myerson who was at the time of publication the co-director for socially inclusive design at the Royal College of Art, London, The Hamlyn Research centre) in _Baseline International Typographics Magazine Number 34, 2001_.

Hi Prakash,  
I hope you found the info you needed. This project got quite complex to be honest, and I ended up conducting sample research at local elementary schools in the Detroit area in order to get sufficient data. If you would like, I can send you copies of any of the research I compiled.

The first round of the project lasted about 10 months, and I have recently picked it back up again. For round two, I am focusing on kinesthetic feedback rather than typography however.

I just did some research on low vision. Check out the nation blind organisations like CNIB (canada) RNIB (uk). the canadian site offers a 'clear print guide' with some results from their research. Verdana, is the way to go acording to them.

_Verdana, is the way to go acording to them._

They don't discount serifed type either.

_I am creating a typeface for this._

While on principle I wouldn't want to discourage novices from designing type for the reading-challenged (two words: Louis Braille), I don't believe that their efforts will be any better than any standard typeface by an experienced designer, in fact, much less effective.

Sure, it's great that some publishers are using such types, but it says more about committment and empowerment than pure functionality.

From both a scientific and design process standpoint, it would make more sense to analyze exisiting typefaces for their suitability for the reading-challenged, and then base one's typeface design on that knowledge, rather than working from abstract principles such as "disambiguation of shapes".
